metadata.case_name: Basant Chandra Ghose v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Appellant is Secretary of Rate Payers Association at Patna, residing in area originally outside municipal limits and not liable to municipal taxation.

On 18th April 1951, area brought within municipal limits by notification under sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of Patna Administration Act 1915, subjecting residents to taxation from 1st April 1951 to 31st March 1952.

High Court of Patna granted leave to appeal under Article 132(1) Constitution on substantial question of law relating to interpretation of Constitution; judgment dated 22nd December 1952 in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 78 of 1952.
In 1911, Province of Bihar and Orissa formed; Bengal Municipal Act 1884 applied; Patna City under Patna City Municipality.
Patna Administration Act 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915) passed to create new municipality for Patna Administration area; came into force 5th January 1916.

Section 3(1)(f) empowered Local Government to extend provisions of Bengal Municipal Act 1884 to Patna with restrictions/modifications; section 5 to cancel/modify orders under section 3; section 6(b) to include local areas in vicinity.
Local Government created Patna Administration Committee and extended selected sections of Bengal Municipal Act to Patna Administration area.
Up to 1922: Patna City under full Bengal Municipal Act; Patna Administration under selected sections; Patna Village free from municipal control.
Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act 1922 (Act VII of 1922) repealed Bengal Municipal Act 1884; applied to Patna City but not Patna Administration.
Patna Administration Amendment Act 1928 (Act IV of 1928) allowed extension of sections from 1922 Act; section 4 deemed prior extensions continued until cancelled.
Notification dated 25th April 1931 cancelled prior extensions, extended selected/modified sections of 1922 Act to Patna Administration.
Constitution of India came into force 26th January 1950; powers of Local Government transferred to Governor of Bihar.
Notification No. MVP-45/50-3645 L.S.G. dated 11th April 1951 (published 18th April 1951) under section 6(b) included Patna Village area within Patna.

Notification No. M Al-201-51-406 L.S.G. dated 23rd April 1951 extended modified section 104 of 1922 Act to Patna Administration and Patna Village, allowing levy of taxes from beginning of quarter after assessment completed.
High Court held impugned sections and notifications intra vires applying In re Delhi Laws Act 1912.

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of Patna Administration Act 1915 permit delegated legislation and are ultra vires.
Whether notifications dated 25th April 1931 and 23rd April 1951 under the Act are ultra vires.
Scope of delegation permissible under Delhi Laws Act case, including power to modify laws without changing policy.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notifications are delegated legislation and bad; sections 3(1)(f) and 5 ultra vires as they permit delegation.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned sections and notifications are intra vires.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: In re Delhi Laws Act 1912 (1951 SCR 747)

court_reasoning.text: Notification of 25th April 1931 does not affect appellant in Patna Village, so not challengeable by him.
Analyzes Delhi Laws Act case: Executive can apply existing/future laws, select parts, with restrictions/modifications not altering essential policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Modifications confined to minor changes, not policy alteration.

court_reasoning.text: Notification of 23rd April 1951 ultra vires as modified section 104 bypasses mandatory hearing/objection procedures in sections 4,5,6 of 1922 Act, changing policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cuts across essential feature of giving inhabitants chance to object.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3(1)(f) intra vires if restrictions/modifications do not effect essential change or alter policy of the Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permits picking sections but subject to Delhi Laws limits.

court_reasoning.text: No need to examine section 5 as no action under it affects appellant.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(f) of Patna Administration Act 1915 is intra vires provided restrictions and modifications do not alter policy or make essential changes.
Notification dated 23rd April 1951 is ultra vires.

precedents_cited.relevance: Defines limits of permissible delegation: application of laws with non-essential modifications allowed.
Permitted selection and application of part of an Act.

statutes_cited.name: Patna Administration Act 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provisions empowering delegation to extend/modify municipal laws to Patna areas; held intra vires with limits.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act 1922 (Bihar and Orissa Act VII of 1922)
statutes_cited.relevance: Sections 4-6 provide mandatory hearing for taxation; section 104 modified and extended for tax levy; modification held to alter policy.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Municipal Act 1884
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed in 1922; selected sections previously extended to Patna Administration.

statutes_cited.name: Patna Administration Amendment Act 1928 (Bihar and Orissa Act IV of 1928)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended 1915 Act to allow extension of 1922 Act sections; deemed prior extensions continued.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate to appeal from High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; section 3(1)(f) held intra vires with restrictions on modifications; notification of 23rd April 1951 held ultra vires; no declaration on 1931 notification or section 5 due to lack of impact on appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that notification dated 23rd April 1951 is ultra vires

key_quotes.text: The power to restrict and modify does not import the power to make essential changes. It is confined to alterations of a minor character...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits on delegation from Delhi Laws Act analysis.

key_quotes.text: one of its essential features is that no municipality competent to tax shall be thrust upon a locality without giving its inhabitants a chance of being heard...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why 1951 notification alters policy of 1922 Act.

key_quotes.text: Subject to that limitation we hold that section 3(1)(f) is intra vires...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of delegation provision.
